content.user_title: Agent Development Guide for Claude Code
content.value_statement: Learn to create powerful autonomous agents for Claude Code plugins with comprehensive guides on structure, system prompts, triggering conditions, and best practices.
actual_capabilities: Provides complete agent file structure with YAML frontmatter format
Includes AI-assisted agent generation templates and prompts
Offers system prompt design patterns for different agent types (analysis, generation, validation, orchestration)
Contains validation scripts to check agent file structure and formatting
Demonstrates triggering examples with context, commentary, and multiple scenarios
Explains agent frontmatter fields: name, description, model, color, tools
Provides complete working examples of production-ready agents (code reviewer, test generator, documentation generator, security analyzer)
limitations: Focused specifically on Claude Code plugin development, not general AI agent frameworks
Requires understanding of Claude Code's tool ecosystem and architecture
Validation script is bash-based and requires Unix-like environment
Does not cover agent deployment or distribution mechanisms
Examples assume familiarity with markdown and YAML syntax

prompt_templates.title: AI-Assisted Agent Generation
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create an agent configuration based on this request: "[YOUR DESCRIPTION]"

Requirements:
1. Extract core intent and responsibilities
2. Design expert persona for the domain
3. Create comprehensive system prompt with clear behavioral boundaries, specific methodologies, edge case handling, and output format
4. Create identifier (lowercase, hyphens, 3-50 chars)
5. Write description with triggering conditions
6. Include 2-3 <example> blocks showing when to use

Return JSON with:
{
  "identifier": "agent-name",
  "whenToUse": "Use this agent when... Examples: <example>...</example>",
  "systemPrompt": "You are..."
}
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to quickly generate a well-structured agent configuration using AI assistance

prompt_templates.title: Request Code Review Agent Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agent that reviews code changes for quality issues, security vulnerabilities, and adherence to best practices. It should be called after code is written and provide specific feedback with file and line references.

best_practices: Include 2-4 concrete triggering examples in the description field with varied phrasings
Use 'inherit' for model field unless agent needs specific model capabilities
Write system prompts in second person (You are..., You will...) addressing the agent directly
Provide clear step-by-step process instructions in the system prompt
Define explicit output format expectations in the system prompt
Restrict tools to minimum needed following principle of least privilege
Choose descriptive agent identifiers (3-50 chars, lowercase, hyphens only)
Include both proactive and reactive triggering examples
Add commentary blocks explaining WHY the agent should trigger in each example
Test agent triggering thoroughly with scenarios similar to examples
Keep system prompts between 500-3,000 characters for optimal clarity
Address edge cases and error scenarios in the system prompt
Use validation script (validate-agent.sh) before deploying agents
anti_patterns: Using generic agent names like 'helper', 'assistant', or 'agent'
Omitting triggering examples from the description field
Writing vague descriptions without specific triggering conditions
Creating system prompts in first person (I am...) instead of second person
Leaving output format undefined in the system prompt
Granting unnecessary tool access (not following least privilege)
Using underscores or special characters in agent identifiers
Writing system prompts over 10,000 characters (too verbose)
Including only one type of triggering example (only explicit OR only proactive)
Skipping the validation step before deployment
Not explaining reasoning in commentary blocks of examples
Forgetting to show the Agent tool invocation in examples

faq.question: What's the difference between an agent and a command in Claude Code?
faq.answer: Agents are autonomous subprocesses that handle complex, multi-step tasks independently and can be triggered automatically based on context. Commands are user-initiated actions that execute when the user explicitly invokes them with slash commands.

faq.question: When should I use 'inherit' vs specific models like 'sonnet' or 'haiku'?
faq.answer: Use 'inherit' (recommended) to have the agent use the same model as the parent conversation unless the agent needs specific model capabilities. Use 'haiku' for fast, simple tasks, 'sonnet' for balanced performance, and 'opus' for most capable but expensive operations.

faq.question: How many triggering examples should I include in the description?
faq.answer: Include 2-4 concrete examples covering different scenarios: explicit requests, implicit requests, proactive triggering, and edge cases. More than 6 makes the description too long.

faq.question: What tools should I grant my agent access to?
faq.answer: Follow the principle of least privilege: grant only the minimum tools needed. For read-only analysis use ['Read', 'Grep', 'Glob'], for code generation use ['Read', 'Write', 'Grep'], and for testing use ['Read', 'Bash', 'Grep']. Omit the tools field only if the agent truly needs full access.

faq.question: How do I validate my agent file before deploying?
faq.answer: Use the validation script: ./scripts/validate-agent.sh agents/your-agent.md. This checks frontmatter structure, required fields, field formats, system prompt presence and length, and example blocks.

faq.question: What makes a good agent identifier?
faq.answer: Use lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens only. Keep it 3-50 characters, starting and ending with alphanumeric. Be descriptive and specific (code-reviewer, test-generator) rather than generic (helper, agent). Avoid underscores and special characters.

faq.question: Should agents be proactive or only reactive?
faq.answer: Most effective agents are both: they trigger on explicit user requests (reactive) and also activate automatically when relevant work is completed (proactive). Include examples of both triggering patterns in your description.

faq.question: How long should the system prompt be?
faq.answer: Aim for 500-3,000 characters (about 1,000-2,000 words) for standard agents. Minimum is 20 characters, but 500+ is recommended. Avoid exceeding 10,000 characters as it becomes too verbose and reduces effectiveness.

permissions: File system access to create agent .md files
